awd_titl_txt: Picture book reading: Investigating a key source of linguistic input for early language development
awd_abstract_narration:
In many homes, schools, and daycare settings, parents and other caregivers engage young children with picture books. This project examines how differences in home picture book reading practices accounts for individual differences in children's language development. This project also involves testing whether greater lexical and grammatical diversity (a characteristic of picture book reading) promote word learning. The text of picture books differs from typical child-directed speech in ways that may be important for language learning. For example, picture book text often describes people and entities not present in the here-and-now, and is characterized by narrative structures unlike typical speech. In addition, the text of picture books contains more unique words and a greater number of complex sentences than typical speech. This means that children who are often read picture books may hear words and sentences that they may not otherwise hear. This project will help researchers understand trajectories of language development and factors that contribute to language development for children. The results of this project will have implications for programs that aim to improve early language outcomes.

This project tests the hypothesis that the distributional differences between child-directed speech and texts may explain the observed benefits of picture book reading. Given the systematic differences between the language contained in picture book text and typical child-directed speech, exposure to picture books may provide children with valuable language learning opportunities. To test this hypothesis, this project first aims to better understand what picture book reading looks like in naturalistic contexts in real homes. Large scale surveys about home reading practices will be administered to parents and primary caregivers. In addition, children and caregivers will be recorded during picture book reading in order to collect data about caregiver-child interactions. Next, families will be given sets of simple or complex picture books to read at home, in order to manipulate the language input that children experience. This manipulation of the language input will provide a means by which the researchers can examine the longitudinal effects of picture book reading on vocabulary and other language outcomes. Given that picture book text is characterized by greater contextual and syntactic diversity than typical speech, this project will demonstrate whether these attributes make picture books a particularly good or poor word-learning tool for children. The results of this project will advance the understanding of the role language input plays in language development, and will clarify the manner in which picture books contribute to language learning trajectories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In many families, caregivers read picture books to young children who are not yet able to read to themselves. There is a lot left to learn about the role that book reading might play in language learning. The language that children hear during picture book reading may be an important and understudied aspect of children’s language environments. We aimed to better understand what goes on in homes when caregivers read to young children, and how the language that’s generated in these contexts might relate to language learning.

One goal was to understand what picture book reading looks like in American homes. First, we performed a large web-based survey of families with children under 30 months of age to understand how often they read picture books, what families do during book reading, and how that might vary across families or vary with the age of the child. We also asked questions about the child’s current language skills as well as questions about other language practices in the home. We will make the raw data available to other researchers, so other people can benefit from the data we collected. Second, we asked a small number of families with children between the ages of 27-37 months to record themselves reading books at home and we transcribed those recordings. We analyzed how features of the book (like how complicated the text is) and characteristic of the families (like how old the child is) contributed to how caregivers read and talk about the book with their children. We also plan to share this dataset, both the raw audio and our written transcripts, with other researchers when the families allowed us to do so. We hope this corpus of over 20 hours of families reading books will be an asset to the field.

Another goal was to understand how language experience from books might relate to language skills, like vocabulary or sentence comprehension. We developed different tasks that can be used with children and adults to assess reading experience and language skills. In one task, we looked at how different patterns in language might help individuals learn new words more efficiently. We can take what we know about how humans learn, and use this to better understand what kinds of language patterns might be good for learning new words. We also developed a task in which we asked individuals to read sentences on a computer screen. We measured how long it took them to read, and how well they answered questions about those sentences. Importantly, some of the sentence structures were much more common in writing than in speech, so we can see if individuals who read more often are better at understanding the sentences that appear more often in writing. It turns out that people who read more are indeed better at comprehending the sentences that appear more often in writing, suggesting that reading, or being read to, might be an important source of language experience for comprehending some kinds of sentences.

Finally, to understand how different kinds of language experience relate to language skills, we recorded full days of 2–3-year old’s audio environments. This will allow us to look at different kinds of language input, like the speech that occurs during book reading or mealtime, and relate that language experience to aspects of what the children say, like the words and sentences they use.

Across all aspects of this project, we gained a better understanding of what picture book reading looks like in homes. In particular, the kinds of language and interactions that occur during book reading, and how this language might be different from other contexts of caregiver-child speech. We can then relate unique aspects of language that a child or adult might encounter during book reading, like vocabulary or complex sentences, to language skills. This helps us understand what book reading might, or might not, contribute to a child’s developing language skills.


Last Modified: 12/21/2022
Modified by: Jessica L Montag
